Since creativity and original work can take different forms in different fields, research is defined in its broadest sense, encompassing artistic and professional activities, as well as more traditional academic inquiry into the humanities, social sciences, and natural sciences. Research extends and enhances classroom learning by enabling students to work one-on-one with faculty members (and, in some areas, also with highly trained postdoctoral fellows and graduate students). In addition to strengthening a student's resume and graduate or professional school applications, such experiences expand understanding of a discipline, engender productive mentoring relationships, and encourage the development of analytic and communication skills that are useful in any profession.   Research varies widely in nature, context, and extent both within and across undergraduate schools at NYU, ranging from research requirements in individual credit-bearing courses to independent study courses and honors theses or projects. The quality of the research enterprise is what truly distinguishes a great university, permitting it to draw in the most talented scholars and the top students. NYU’s faculty are at the forefront of their scholarly disciplines, and their research helps shape the understanding of an enormous range of academic fields: from the mathematical sciences to economics, from philosophy to neural science, from art history to sociology. In recognition of the quality of this research, NYU received approximately $200 million in government funds in 2008.     NYU’s also makes it own major commitments to the research enterprise. Through the Partners Initiative, first announced in 2004, the University is increasing tenured and tenure-track positions in the arts and sciences by 20% -- 125 additional faculty positions. And this growth has been accompanied significant investment in new facilities to support faculty scholarship in genomics research and in soft condensed matter physics, as well as through major renovations of laboratories in the Silver Center, to cite just a few examples. In addition, the Provost’s Office oversees research grants program to allow faculty to compete for additional funding to pursue research.            The Role of Libraries at a  Research University   A world-class research institution needs a world-class library with deep and ever expanding resources in all formats. NYU Libraries supports research with a broad range of instructional services and collections that include, for example, more than 5.9 million volumes, 163,000 sound and video recordings, and more than a million e-books and databases. The NYU community conducted more than 4.7 million BobCat catalog searches last year and visited library.nyu.edu more than 2.5 million times.   NYU Libraries’ flagship facility is the striking, 12-story Elmer Holmes Bobst Library on Washington Square. Designed by Philip Johnson and Richard Foster, it serves as a center for scholarship and a hub of the University community's intellectual life. Tory Dent Research Scholarship in Creative Writing, CWP | NYU                         NEW YORK UNIVERSITY       ARTS AND SCIENCE       COLLEGE OF ARTS AND SCIENCE       GRADUATE SCHOOL OF ARTS AND SCIENCE                           Creative Writing Program                                                                                                Back to  previous page                Printer Friendly       Tory Dent Research Scholarship in Creative Writing            The Tory Dent Research Scholarship in Creative Writing , made  possible by a generous donor and named for acclaimed American poet Tory Dent , is part of the CAS Dean's Undergraduate  Research Fund (DURF). The Scholarship provides summer support for an undergraduate  student to pursue research or travel in connection with a writing project. The  Scholarship might also be used to fund attendance at a writing conference or  summer writing program, or to support “work release” from summer employment for  the purposes of focusing on a writing project.  Applicants must be  current freshmen, sophomores, juniors, or first-term seniors in the College of Arts and Science (CAS). The Creative Writing Program will review all applications and make awards  of up to $1,250. To apply, please fill out the form here and email a writing sample (3 poems or up to 1500 words of prose) to cwp.ug.awards@nyu.edu by Monday, March 9, 2015 . Please use the subject line “TDRS Writing Sample" and be sure to include your N# in your email. The application form includes the following questions: >What is the title of your proposed project? >Please summarize your project. What will your end product be? What process do you plan to employ to achieve this? >Please provide a timeline, including the   estimated start/end dates and estimated hours per week dedicated to the   work. >Please provide an itemized budget for your project. >If your project involves travel, please describe the academic and social support networks available to you at the requested location. >Why is this project important to me as a writer? Best of luck! 2015 Recipients Haley Steinberg  was awarded $725 towards travel expenses for her project “The Vegas Complex.” André-Naquian Wheeler was awarded $725 for travel expenses and work release for his project "Second Coming." 2014 Recipient  Joshua White was awarded $1,250 towards research expenses and work release for his project “Land: A Survey of West Virginia.” 2013 Recipient  Samantha Harrison was awarded $1,250 towards travel and expenses for her project “Writing the Rainforest.”  2012 Recipient  Megan Myscofski was awarded $1,250 towards travel and expenses for her project “Prinzessinnen Street Garden.”  2011 Recipients Joshua Gaither was awarded $400 towards summer work release and supplies, for his project “Silk and Vellum: Matching East and West in Poetry.” Erica Martin was awarded $1,175 for travel, supplies, and summer work release, in support of her project “A Novel Ghana.” Martin Spasov was awarded $850 for summer work release, travel, and supplies, in support of his project “A Letter Home.” 2010 Recipients Diana E. Kole was awarded $450 towards the purchase of contemporary   novellas and summer work release so that she could complete her own novella. Eugene Reznik    was awarded $902 for travel supplies and summer work release, in   support of research for his “roaming, wandering, existential,   metafictive, vignette-driven ‘road’ novel." 2009 Recipients Patrick Blagrave   was awarded $600 towards summer work release and the purchase of  books to explore “the connection between the science of physics and the  art of poetry” and to produce an original manuscript. Click here to read "Relativity," a poem from Patrick's collection, Redshift: Sonnets on Physics. Greg Solano was awarded $650 to attend Semana Santa (Holy Week) in Seville, Spain, and produce original poetry and a short story about his time there.
